questions.text: 30-year-old female ultrasonography reveals a 6x5 cm mass in the right ovary. Histologic sections from this ovarian mass reveal a papillary tumour with multiple, scattered small, round, laminated calcifications. What is a type of cell injury in laminated structure present in tumour?
questions.solution:
Psammoma Bodies and Dystrophic Calcification:

  • Psammoma bodies are lamellated configurations resembling grains of sand.
  • They are formed through the progressive acquisition of outer layers.
  • Dystrophic calcification is a type of cell injury characterized by the deposition of calcium salts.
  • It occurs in damaged or dying tissues.
  • Psammoma bodies are a hallmark of dystrophic calcification.
  • Dystrophic calcification happens locally, often in areas of tissue damage or inflammation.
  • This occurs despite normal serum levels of calcium and without disturbances in calcium metabolism.

Incorrect Options:

A) Apoptosis:

  • Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process.
  • It does not involve the deposition of calcium salts.
  • It is a highly regulated mechanism of cell death that occurs in a controlled manner.
  • It does not result in the formation of calcifications.

C) Enzymatic Necrosis:

  • Enzymatic necrosis is a type of cell death resulting from the release of enzymes from damaged cells.
  • While enzymatic processes can contribute to tissue damage and inflammation, they do not lead to the formation of calcifications.
  • Enzymatic necrosis typically involves the digestion of cellular components.

D) Metastatic Calcification:

  • Metastatic calcification is a type of calcification that occurs in otherwise normal tissues.
  • It results from systemic factors, particularly hypercalcemia.
  • It affects various tissues throughout the body, including blood vessels, kidneys and lungs.
  • In the described case, calcifications are localized within the ovarian tumor, making metastatic calcification unlikely.

Common Cancers Associated with Psammoma Bodies:

  • M: Meningioma, Mesothelioma
  • O: Papillary carcinoma of Ovary
  • S: Papillary carcinoma of salivary gland
  • T: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid
  • P: Prolactinoma
  • G: Glucagonoma

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg:65

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
In which of the following condition the cell can recover to its original state when the stress is eliminated?
i.Hypertrophy
ii.Hyperplasia
iii.Atrophy
iv.Metaplasia
questions.solution:
• Adaptation are reversible changes in the size, number, phenotype, metabolic activity, or functions of cells in response to changes in their environment.

CELLULAR ADAPTATIONS TO STRESS:

  • Hypertrophy: Increased cell and organ size, often in response to increased workload; induced by growth factors produced in response to mechanical stress or other stimuli; occurs in tissues incapable of cell division
  • Hyperplasia: Increased cell numbers in response to hormones and other growth factors; occurs in tissues whose cells are able to divide or contain abundant tissue stem cells.
  • Atrophy: Decreased cell and organ size, as a result of decreased nutrient supply or disuse, associated with decreased synthesis of cellular building blocks and increased breakdown of cellular organelles and autophagy.
  • Metaplasia: Change in phenotype of differentiated cells, often in response to chronic irritation, that makes cells better able to withstand the stress, usually induced by altered differentiation pathway of tissue stem cells. This may result in reduced functions or increased propensity for malignant transformation

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg:54

questions.text: A 36-year-old obese woman has been experiencing heartburn from gastric reflux for the past 5 years after eating large meals. She undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and a biopsy specimen of the distal esophagus is obtained. Which of the following stain shown in figure can help in making the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Inflammation from reflux of gastric acid has resulted in replacement of normal esophageal squamous epithelium by intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Such conversion of one adult cell type into another cell type is called metaplasia and it occurs when stimuli reprogram stem cells. These goblet cells contain acidic mucin picked by alcian blue.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th edition, Chapter - 2, pg 34

questions.text: The tumour suppressor gene p53 induces to inhibit cell cycle at which phase?
questions.solution:
• The tumour suppressor gene that is most commonly affected by point mutations in cancer is TP53, a prototypical "guardian" type tumour suppressor gene.
  • DNA damage leads to activation of p53 by phosphorylation.
  • Activated p53 drives transcription of CDKN1A(p21), which prevents RB phosphorylation, thereby causing a G1-S block in the cell cycle.
  • This pause allows the cells to repair the DNA damage.
  • If the DNA can be repaired, p53 activates other genes to fix the damage. If the DNA cannot be repaired, this protein prevents the cell from dividing and signals it to undergo apoptosis. By stopping cells with mutated or damaged DNA from dividing, p53 helps prevent the development of tumors.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page Number 212 & 213.

questions.text: Which of the following tumour suppression gene mutation is associated with endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Important tumor suppressor called PTEN is a negative inhibitor of PI3 kinase and is frequently mutated in carcinomas, certain leukemias and other cancers as well.

Mutations in mismatch repair genes and the tumor suppressor gene PTEN are early events in the stepwise development of endometrioid carcinoma. Women with germline mutations in PTEN(Cowden Syndrome) and germline alterations in DNA mismatch repair genes(Lynch Syndrome) are at high risk for this cancer. TP53 mutations occur but are relatively uncommon and are late events in the genesis of this tumor type.

The PTEN gene provides instructions for making an enzyme that is found in almost all tissues in the body. The enzyme acts as a tumor suppressor, which means that it helps regulate cell division by keeping cells from growing and dividing(proliferating) too rapidly or in an uncontrolled way.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg: 207, 724.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an inherited cancer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Inherited cancer syndromes:

  1. Familial retinoblastoma
  2. Familial adenomatous polyps of the colon
  3. Multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes
  4. Neurofibromatosis types 1 and 2
  5. Von Hippel - Lindau syndrome

Familial cancers:

  1. Breast cancer
  2. Ovarian cancer
  3. Colonic cancer other than familial adenomatous polyps

Autosomal Recessive syndromes of Defective DNA Repair:

  1. Xeroderma pigmentosum
  2. Ataxia telangiectasia
  3. Bloom syndrome
  4. Fanconi anemia

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page Number-201.

choices.text: The C3b breakdown product of complement

questions.text: Following is/are major opsonin(s) required for opsonization of microbes EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The efficiency of phagocytosis is greatly enhanced when microbes are opsonized(coated) by specific proteins(opsonins) for which the phagocytes express high-affinity receptors.
  • The major opsonins are immunoglobulin(Ig)G antibodies, the C3b breakdown product of complement activation and certain plasma lectins, notably mannose-binding lectin, all of which are recognized by specific receptors on leukocytes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 67.

questions.text: Lewis triple response is caused by:
questions.solution:
Histamine is vasoactive amine that is located in most body tissues but is highly concentrated in the lungs, skin and gastrointestinal tract.

It is stored in mast cell and basophils. When it is injected intradermally, it causes the triple response:

  • Red spot: due to dilatation
  • Wheal: due to exudation of fluid from capillaries
  • Flare: Redness in surrounding area due to arterial dilatation

Reference: Goodman and Gilman, 10th ed, Pg: 650.

choices.text: Inability to form membrane attack complex

questions.text: 7-year-old girl had bacterial meningitis and was on penicillin 2 years back. At present she is complaining of hemorrhagic skin lesions. What can be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
• Patient having deficiency of complement factors that forms membrane attack complex experience recurrent infection by Neisseria species.
  • The deposition of the MAC on cells drills holes in the cell membrane, making the cells permeable to water and ions and resulting in their osmotic death(lysis).
  • This function of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria bacteria.
  • Hence, deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to infections by the Neisseria species meningococci and gonococci.
  • Patients with complement deficiencies, these microbes can cause serious disseminated infections.

Option A: T cell dysfunction is thymic hypoplasia seen in Di George Syndrome. In this condition there is congenital deficiency of the thymus and parathyroid gland.

Option B: Chronic granulomatous infection is an example of deficient intracellular killing.

Option C: Young adults infected with Neisseria meningitis may be at increased risk of disseminated infection if they produce too much IgA antibody.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 76.

questions.text: Performed antibodies cause:
questions.solution:
• Hyper acute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.
  • The preformed antibodies may be natural IgM antibodies specific for blood group antigens or may be antibodies specific for allogeneic.
  • Hyperacute rejection occurs a few minutes after the transplant when the antigens are completely unmatched. The tissue must be removed right away so the recipient does not die. This type of rejection is seen when a recipient is given the wrong type of blood. Hyperacute rejection is usually caused by specific antibodies against the graft and occurs within minutes or hours after grafting. Acute rejection occurs days or weeks after transplantation and can be caused by specific lymphocytes in the recipient that recognize human leukocyte antigens in the tissue or organ grafted.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 163.

questions.text: Which of the following classification of Lupus nephritis is defined by involvement of fewer than 50% of all glomeruli. The lesions may be segmental or global?
questions.solution:
Following is the classification of Lupus nephritis:

  • Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis(class I) is very uncommon and is characterized by immune complex deposition in the mesangium, identified by immunofluorescence and by electron microscopy, but without structural changes by light microscopy.
  • Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis(class II) is characterized by mesangial cell proliferation, often accompanied by accumulation of mesangial matrix and granular mesangial deposits of immunoglobulin and complement without involvement of glomerular capillaries.
  • Focal lupus nephritis(class III) is defined by involvement of fewer than 50% of all glomeruli. The lesions may be segmental(affecting only a portion of the glomerulus) or global(involving the entire glomerulus). Affected glomeruli may exhibit swelling and proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells associated with leukocyte accumulation, capillary necrosis and hyaline thrombi. Often, there also is extracapillary proliferation associated with focal necrosis and crescent formation. The clinical presentation ranges from mild hematuria and proteinuria to acute renal insufficiency. Red blood cell casts in the urine are common when the disease is active. Some patients progress to diffuse glomerulonephritis. The active(or proliferative) inflammatory lesions can heal completely or lead to chronic global or segmental glomerular scarring.
  • Diffuse lupus nephritis(class IV) is the most common and severe form of lupus nephritis. The lesions are identical to those in class III, but differ in extent; in diffuse lupus nephritis, half or more of the glomeruli are affected. Involved glomeruli show proliferation of endothelial, mesangial and epithelial cells, with the latter producing cellular crescents that fill Bowman's space. Subendothelial immune complex deposits may create a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, forming "wire-loop" structures on light microscopy. Immune complexes can be readily detected by electron microscopy and immunofluorescence. Lesions may progress to scarring of glomeruli. Patients with diffuse glomerulonephritis are usually symptomatic, showing hematuria as well as proteinuria. Hypertension and mild to severe renal insufficiency also are common.
  • Membranous lupus nephritis(class V) is characterized by diffuse thickening of the capillary walls due to deposition of subepithelial immune complexes, similar to idiopathic membranous nephropathy. The immune complexes are usually accompanied by increased production of basement membrane-like material, resulting in "holes" and "spikes" on silver stain. This lesion is usually accompanied by severe proteinuria or nephrotic syndrome and may occur concurrently with focal or diffuse lupus nephritis.
  • Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis(class VI) is characterized by sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli and represents end-stage renal disease.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg: 154.

questions.text: 62-year-old female has had worsening congestive heart failure for 3 years. Echocardiogram shows a restrictive cardiomyopathy. Cardiac catheterization shows no coronary artery disease, but right endomyocardial biopsy shows myocardial replacement with acellular, eosinophilic material on haematoxylin and eosin stain. On congo red stains it appear as apple green birefringence on polarizing microscope. What is this material?
questions.solution:
Amyloidosis of the heart may occur in any form of systemic amyloidosis. It also is the major organ involved in senile systemic amyloidosis. The heart may be enlarged and firm, but more often it shows no appreciable change on gross inspection. Histologically the deposits begin as focal subendocardial accumulations and within the myocardium between the muscle fibers. Expansion of these myocardial deposits eventually causes pressure atrophy of myocardial fibers. When the amyloid deposits are subendocardial, the conduction system may be damaged, accounting for the electrocardiographic abnormalities noted in some patients.

The diagnosis of amyloidosis is based on histopathology. With the light microscope and hematoxylin and eosin stains, amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance. The most widely used is the Congo red stain, which under ordinary light gives a pink or red color to tissue deposits, but far more striking and specific is the green birefringence of the stained amyloid when observed by polarizing microscopy. This staining reaction is shared by all forms of amyloid and is imparted by the crossed β-pleated sheet configuration of amyloid fibrils. Confirmation can be obtained by electron microscopy, which reveals 7-10nm infinite long thin fibrils. Subtyping of amyloid is most reliably done by mass spectroscopy, as immunohistochemical stains are not entirely sensitive or specific.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg: 186.

questions.text: What is the type of chromosomal alteration depicted in the picture below?
questions.solution:
• A special pattern of translocation involving two acrocentric chromosomes is called centric fusion type or Robertsonian translocation.
  • The breaks typically occur close to the centromere, affecting the short arms of both chromosomes.
  • Transfer of the segments leads to one very large chromosome and one extremely small one.
  • Robertsonian translocation(rob) is a chromosomal abnormality wherein a certain type of a chromosome becomes attached to another. It is the most common form of chromosomal translocation in humans, affecting 1 out of every 1,000 babies born. It does not usually cause health difficulties, but in some cases can result in genetic disorders such as Down's syndrome and Patau syndrome. Robertsonian translocations result in a reduction in the number of chromosomes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page Number-263.

questions.text: Which amongst the following autosomal inheritance has LDL receptor deficiency?
questions.solution:
Familial hypercholesterolemia resulting from mutations in the ldlr, apob or pcsk9 gene have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Autosomal dominant inheritance means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. An affected person typically inherits one altered copy of the gene from an affected parent and one normal copy of the gene from the other parent.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg: 245

choices.text: Gap between first and second toe

questions.text: One of these traits is not seen in a person with Down Syndrome:
questions.solution:
• Features of Down syndrome:

Hematological manifestation with downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoeisis and acute leukemias (aml m7, being most common in age <4 years and all common >4 years )

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed Pg: 265

choices.text: Cytokine secretion from Helper T cells
Immune complex deposition followed by inflammation
Mast cell mediated secretion of vasoactive amines
Eosinophil activation and mediated tissue injury

questions.text: A patient has undergone the following test to identify aberrant immune reactions. What is the basic mechanism of what is being observed here?
questions.solution:
• When a person who was sensitized by exposure to an allergen is reexposed to the allergen, the allergen binds to antigen-specific IgE molecules on mast cells, usually at or near the site of allergen entry.
  • Cross-linking of these IgE molecules triggers a series of biochemical signals that culminate in the secretion of various mediators from the mast cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 137.

questions.text: Which of the following type of aberrant immune reactions may be diagnosed by a Coomb's test?
questions.solution:
• Antibody-mediated(type II) hypersensitivity disorders are caused by antibodies directed against target antigens on the surface of cells or other tissue components.
  • The antigens may be normal molecules intrinsic to cell membranes or in the extracellular matrix or they may be adsorbed exogenous antigens(e.g., a drug metabolite).
  • A Coombs test, also known as antiglobulin test, is either of two blood tests used in immunohematology. They are the direct and indirect Coombs tests. The direct Coombs test detects antibodies that are stuck to the surface of the red blood cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 139.

questions.text: A patient suffers from gout. His uric acid levels are very high. Which of the following molecule will recognize this danger associated molecular pattern
questions.solution:
Danger associated molecular patterns are recognized by NOD like receptors

Pathogen associated molecular patterns are recognized by toll like receptors and RIG like receptors

NET are involved in inflammation

Reference: Robbins 10th ed, 6th chapter, pg 192

choices.text: Only ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Subepithelial deposits in kidney is/are seen in which of the following disease/s?
i. MPGN-1( Membranous proliferative GN)
ii. PSGN(Post streptococcal GN)
iii. Membranous GN
iv. GPS (good-pasture syndrome)
questions.solution:
• Subepithelial deposits located at the base of the podocyte foot processes outside the GBM
  • In PSGN There may be occasional mesangial and small subendothelial deposits but the most consistent diagnostic change is hump type, large, subepithelial deposits without significant glomerular basement membrane reaction
  • Membranous GN is thought to be caused by immune-complex deposition in the glomerular tuft, and is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Repeated (chronic) injection of soluble antigens produces this lesion, characterized by subepithelial immune-complex (IgG and C3) deposition, recognized light microscopically with silver stains as spikes of argyrophilic material on the epithelial surface of the basement membrane.
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a lesion defined by subendothelial and mesangial deposits with endocapillary hypercellularity and double contours of glomerular basement membranes.
  • Goodpasture's syndrome is characterized by deposits of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, both in the kidney glomerulus and in the lung alveoli, causing glomerulonephritis and pulmonary bleeding.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th edition, Page- 556

questions.text: Identify the morphology in blood vessel of given H & E stain section that favours the diagnosis of benign nephrosclerosis?
questions.solution:
• The histology figure reflects; high-power view of two arterioles with hyaline deposition, marked thickening of the walls, and a narrowed lumen.
  • Nephrosclerosis refers to sclerosis of small renal arteries and arterioles that is strongly associated with hypertension. The characteristic morphologic alterations of the small arterioles are called hyaline arteriolosclerosis, while the arteries show fibrous intimal and medial thickening often resulting in luminal narrowing. The vascular changes cause ischemia, which leads to various combinations of interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, and focal global glomerulosclerosis.
  • Grossly, the kidneys are symmetrically atrophic. Typically the renal surface shows diffuse, fine granularity that resembles grain leather. Microscopically, the most prominent change is hyaline thickening of the walls of the arterioles, known as hyaline arteriolosclerosis. This appears as a homogeneous, pink hyaline thickening, at the expense of the vessel lumina, with loss of underlying cellular detail.
  • The narrowing of the lumen results in markedly decreased blood flow through the affected vessels, with consequent ischemia and renal atrophy. In advanced cases of arterio nephrosclerosis,the glomerular tufts may become sclerosed. Diffuse tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis are present, but inflammatory infiltrates are absent or scant. The larger blood vessels (interlobar and arcuate arteries) show intimal thickening with replication of internal elastic lamina along with fibrous thickening of the media (fibroelastic hyperplasia).

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th edition, Page- 570

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented to the clinic with history of Fatigue and tiredness. On investigation he was found to have Hb values of 9 gm%, MCV of 101fl. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic hematology (RBCs) and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
• MCV - 101fl is suggestive of macrocytosis
  • Most commonly (especially when the increase in size is mild, and just above normal range) the cause is bone marrow dysplasia secondary to alcohol abuse and chronic alcoholism, Poor absorption of vitamin B12 in the digestive tract can also cause macrocytosis.
  • Macrocytosis is frequently linked to alcoholism, with or without liver disease. In fact, it is purported to be one of the most common causes of non megaloblastic macrocytosis.
  • In cases of macrocytosis related to alcoholism the elevated MCV may be due to the direct effect of the alcohol, liver disease and/or folate deficiency.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition Chapter 18, pg 841

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with respiratory distress which is increasing gradually since 3 years at a very slow pace. He explains that he belongs to lower socioeconomic status so he is working as stone carver since 30 years. Chest X-ray performed, shows nodularity in the upper zone of the lung. He was admitted and treated conservatively. But after 2 days patient died due to congestive heart failure. Autopsy was done and histopathological examination done from nodular area image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
(a) Anthracosis (choice a) by itself does not cause restrictive lung disease.

(b) Asbestosis (choice b) is characterized by interstitial fibrosis.

(c) The nodules of sarcoidosis are not fibrotic.

(d) Silicosis is caused by inhalation of small crystals of quartz (silicon dioxide), which are generated by stone cutting, sandblasting, and mining. The condition is marked by the insidious development of fibrotic pulmonary nodules containing quartz crystals. The disease may be asymptomatic for prolonged periods of time or may cause only mild to moderate dyspnea. Continued exposure may lead to progressive fibrosis and severe respiratory embarrassment.

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed, pg 694

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with persistent headache associated with nausea and vomiting. On clinical examination it is found to have raised intracranial pressure due to lesion in posterior fossa. On gadolinium enhanced MRI shows well circumscribed mass with mild enhancement. After craniotomy tissue is taken for diagnosis and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ependymomas can develop in patients of any age, with reported patient ages ranging from birth to 81 years. Ependymomas may occur along the ventricular system or spinal canal, in the cerebral hemispheres, or at extra CNS sites. Overall, 60% of the tumors develop in the posterior fossa, 30% in the supratentorial compartment. The clinical manifestations depend on tumor localization. Ependymomas of the posterior fossa can present with signs and symptoms of hydrocephalus and raised intracranial pressure, such as headache, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI shows well-circumscribed masses with various degrees of contrast enhancement. Ventricular obstruction or brain stem displacement and hydrocephalus are common accompanying features.

Classic ependymoma is a well-delineated glioma with monomorphic cells characterized by a variable density and round to oval nuclei with speckled nuclear chromatin. The key histological features are perivascular anucleate zones (pseudorosettes) and (true) ependymal rosettes. The pseudorosettes are composed of tumor cells radially arranged around blood vessels, creating perivascular anucleate zones of fine fibrillary processes. The ependymal rosettes and tubular canals are composed of bland cuboidal or columnar tumor cells arranged around a central lumen.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition, Chapter - 28 pg 1293

choices.text: Thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy
Enlargement of mucus-secreting glands of trachea and bronchi
Chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate (lymphocytes and macrophages)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of productive cough since 4 months, and he had such symptoms every year since 3 years. He gave a history of excessive smoking from long duration due to stress. What will be the histopathological findings in such disease in airway if biopsy is taken, image of which is shown below. What is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
The characteristic microscopic features of chronic bronchitis are chronic inflammation of the airways (predominantly lymphocytes and macrophages); thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy, deposition of extracellular matrix in the muscle layer, and peribronchial fibrosis; goblet cell hyperplasia; and enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands of the trachea and bronchi. Of these, the most striking change is an increase in the size of the mucous glands. This increase can be assessed by the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the cartilage (Reid index).

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed, pg 681

questions.text: Which of the following condition is shown below?
questions.solution:
Plexiform neurofibroma is an uncommon variant of neurofibroma, a benign tumor of peripheral nerves (WHO grade I), arising from a proliferation of all neural elements. Plexiform neurofibroma are essentially pathognomonic of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1).

NF-1:

  • Gene mutated is located on chromosome 17q
  • Characterized by cafe-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, dysplasia of lesser wing of sphenoid and risk of developing meningioma

NF-2:

  • Due to mutation in gene located on chromosome 22q
  • Characterized by cafe-au-lait spots and bilateral vestibular schwannoma Marfan Syndrome
  • Due to defect in Fibrillin gene on chromosome 15.
  • Characterized by hyper flexibility of joints, subluxation of lens and cardiac problems (mitral valve prolapse, bicuspid aortic valve) Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome
  • Gene is located on chromosome 3p
  • High risk of developing clear cell renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma, pheochromocytoma, retina hemangioblastoma.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition, Chapter - 28 pg 1302
